title: Should League have an Official Webcomic?
body:
http://i.imgur.com/K5Ztcuy.png



**There was at one point in time, a MOBA by the name of Dawngate being developed by EA. Though it looked promising, it was eventually cancelled due the game's inability to develop a large community by the end of it's Open Beta. I'm bringing up this story because Dawngate had an incredibly interesting way of developing it's lore which I honestly think League should adopt. It had a Webcomic, known as "The Dawngate Chronicles". **

Here's an example of some of the pages. 
https://cmmedia.global.ssl.fastly.net/459a1345f29ce1ed0455/24892348/960x1250.jpeg
https://mir-s3-cdn-cf.behance.net/project_modules/disp/5ed4f717114079.562b5e739f1ed.jpg

**The comic was updated 3 times a week (Monday, Wednesday and Friday) and had a few story arcs throughout it's run, usually with the focus of familiarizing readers with the Heroes in the game. It was good, like really freaking good. The art was amazing, the stories were engaging and fun, being able to see the characters you play as interact with their world and other Heroes, it was all just so well done. It is in my eyes, how MOBA lore should be handled. The Poppy and Ekko comics are some of the most well received pieces of Lore ever created, Why can't a Webcomic be the main way League's stories are told?**

replies.body:
Hi League ppls! I was Dawngate's EP. Just got pointed here by the twitters and wanted to write a thing ... 

Story is ironically challenging in this genre: MOBAs are games defined by characters, yet the gameplay can't afford the moments required to develop those characters beyond their mechanics. Nor should it: games are _not_ stories, and in MOBA, the expression of skill through the character is not only paramount, it's really all that matters. Gameplay first. No time for cut-scenes in a 10 player pvp game!

But good stories and the characters that bring them to life are fucking beautiful, and they make the expression of the character through those mechanics so much more meaningful and fun! Somehow, games _are_ stories, or they want to be ... they certainly share something core with them through agency and the resulting connection we all have as players.

So while gameplay was always paramount, we also invested in deep world-building for Dawngate, and in funny ideas like match-up specific VO between characters, and in vehicles like the Dawngate Chronicles web comic to explore how to could bring characters to life. To be honest, It was all for science. We did it because we dug it and believed in it and we wanted to bring gameplay and story closer together: some of it worked, some of it didn't.

So on behalf of the crew who brought the Dawngate Chronicles to life: so glad you guys dug it ... we all loved making it!

"Splash of color!" :)
Dawngate was an absolute treasure. Thank you so much for working on it.

Hey Paradoxiq! This is a silly question but do you ever think that there will be a chance to revitalize the story or is that also in EAs vault? I personally was really looking forward to Viridians story and more of Freia (my personal favorite character in game and in Lore).
EA owns all the things.
SADNESS D:

I don't agree that gameplay should be "paramount". I would argue that games are a spectrum and that not all games have or need stories but others are all about story and are the better for it. Moba's are certainly more difficult genre of games trying to find that balance but you guys were definitely close. Perhaps the closest so far. But just because something is difficult doesn't mean it doesn't deserve to be explored to its fullest. Dismissing story just feels lazy and the easy way out.

We certainly didn't dismiss story, which was the point of my post. Acknowledging difficulty and sharing the development challenge was the goal there. Sorry if we missed each other on that! :)

For us, gameplay _is_ paramount, and for Dawngate (and I'd argue, for the modern experience of MOBA as a genre), it needs to be. That was simply one of our values at Waystone, just as it is at our new studio. So the challenge was: how do we honor that and find a way to equally honor good storytelling.

Sorry, I guess I misread your post as trying to provide a reason why Riot was falling short on their lore. I don't feel its necessary especially since you guys at Dawngate seemed to be on the right track of integrating moba gameplay with interesting and engaging storytelling. While you guys set a high standard to reach, Riot should be already there and trying to exceed it. 

Riot obviously had issues that they seem to be turning around on (slowly). And they seem to be trying to provide more on the lore front. They just haven't found their own voice yet. And all the faltering and slow progress is frustrating as a fan of both games, esp. since dawngate is gone now and League has all the potential to fill that void. 

Well, here's hoping league can meet my expectations but at this point its slim. And best of luck to you guys to your new game studio, I'm eagerly waiting to see what you guys put out.
They're a smart bunch there at Riot, but I get where you're at. I'm optimistic they'll continue to explore and find ways forward that are right for them and for their game.

You guys were doing an amazing job over there, I'm sorry that EA decided to pull the plug. The reason this stuck in my head for so long was because it was THAT good. The Webcomic format allowed for me to be continually invested in these characters since there was always a new update to look forward too. 
http://hydra-media.cursecdn.com/dawngate.gamepedia.com/a/a5/1.14.jpg
Look at Voluc's face. God dammit, I had such pity for that character. The feels man. Everytime I died to him in-game I would think "it's ok, he's been through a lot". 

I would honestly rather have a continual and scheduled release of small content than giant pages of text every 3+ months. I mean the writers at Riot tell good stories, but it just comes as such a massive wave. I'm not even looking for some crazy overarching plot that involved all 128 champions. I would be completely satisfied with a mini-arc of Ekko's adventures with his buddies in Zaun for ~30 pages, then maybe a jump to Quinn on one of her scouting missions in the Freljord.

GAH!  I need to stop looking at this thread, all the feels!

That character pretty much had me in emo mode the whole time I saw him on the map.  

[This lore](http://dawngate.gamepedia.com/Voluc) is just so sad, one of the worst for the feels in ANY game I've played.

I have to agree on the smaller, constant lore over the massive lore dumps that we have gotten.  They're nice every once in a while, but would rather had a weekly (or biweekly) comic over that.

Honestly, you guys set the standard for me for storytelling for MOBAS.  You had a story that weaved the gameplay into it, and you ENCOURAGED us to pay attention to your lore, and to have the feels for all the characters, even the one's we didn't like.  They were larger than life, but still human.  They didn't feel like flat, one note songs, even when they were.

Favourite page in the whole comic

http://hydra-media.cursecdn.com/dawngate.gamepedia.com/5/58/5.3.jpg

While I eventually stopped playing the game for various reasons, I absolutely adored the comic and I was sad to see it die out along with the game. I would love to see LoL attempt something similar

when you had pages like the above and pages like this:

(http://i.imgur.com/m83TmgV.jpg)

it was good.

much yes

basically every strip with Renzo was pure gold, as well as the bit with vex... and ronan... and freia...

and pretty much the rest of the comic. can't think of any bit that straight-up sucked

The lore (and everything surrounding it) was just. . . . . amazing.

It was only after reading the strip that I actually started to not loathe Renzo, because his floofing around the map combined with his referring to himself only in the third person just grated on me for some reason.  

Seeing him as he was there just put it all into perspective for me.

Kinda surprised King of Masks hasn't shown up yet in this thread. 

Back on topic, while I think a comic would be great for league I'm not convinced that Riot has an actual overarching narrative story for the game. League has the problem that it might just have too many "main" characters that it might be nearly impossible to give a satisfying storyline for each. Maybe Riot could pull it off but I wouldn't get my hopes up.
Man, I miss Dawngate. Salous was my favorite hero in any moba I've played.

Dawngate was a brilliant MOBA filled with SO MUCH potential. It wasn't like STRIFE, just trying to cash in on a popular market, but it was innovative, fresh, and really really fun. The art style made my jaw drop so many times (seriously, the Eastern art style is really underused in these games) and the gameplay was so engaging.

I really REALLY hope someone picks up ownership of Dawngate and makes it the excellent MOBA it could have been.

If Dawngate comes back, I would instantly play again. Dibbs and crew were the best heroes I've ever played and the online web comic made me so invested in it and really brought the characters to life!
So much potential, but it had to be backed by EA... ugh... the people who were actually working on the game though, they were actually really fun guys. They brought livestreams and such! They even were cool and livestreamed what they were gonna release when EA decided to shut it down.

If Dawngate came back, you would hear a 30 year old man "Squee!!!!" like a Japanese Schoolgirl. 

Yes, the WHOLE WORLD WOULD HEAR ME.

But a webcomic would remove any hope of connecting the lore and gameplay. I know they aren't trying to do that, but I'm holding out hope.

How so?

Mainly in how the certain champions would develop. Let's say Poppy realizes she's the hero in a comic. Her in game personality would not reflect this...unless they did a story related skin...I don't know why I wasn't considering that.

The other part of that webcomic, is that players through the game itself, had a voice as to how the various arcs could go.  Most of the pivot points in the story which had two of the characters in conflict, had a few days where players could play as one of the characters to show their support.
